review.title: Tractable Combinations of Global Constraints
review.abstract: We study the complexity of constraint satisfaction problems involving global constraints, i.e., special-purpose constraints provided by a solver and represented implicitly by a parametrised algorithm. Such constraints are widely used; indeed, they are one of the key reasons for the success of constraint programming in solving real-world problems.
histories: To appear in proceedings of CP'13, LNCS 8124. arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1307.1790
review.COMMENTS: To appear in proceedings of CP'13, LNCS 8124. arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1307.1790

sections.heading: 5 Polynomial-time Reductions
sections.text: In this section, we will show that for each constraint problem over a cooperating catalog, a set of variables, all occurring in exactly the same set of constraints, can be replaced by a single new variable with an appropriate domain to give a polynomial time shortening to a smaller instance. Let's be G = < V > a hypergraph. G's dual G class is a hypergraph with vertex set H and a hyperedge {h} for each v instance. As demonstrated in Example 5, instances with a single global constraint may already be NP-complete [26], so we cannot hope to achieve tractability by structural restrictions alone.

In other words, notions such as bounded degree of cyclicity [21] or bounded hypertree width [18] are not sufficient to ensure tractability in the framework of global constraints, where the arity of individual constraints is unbounded.

metadata.abstractText: We study the complexity of constraint satisfaction problems involving global constraints, i.e., special-purpose constraints provided by a solver and represented implicitly by a parametrised algorithm. Such constraints are widely used; indeed, they are one of the key reasons for the success of constraint programming in solving real-world problems. Previous work has focused on the development of efficient propagators for individual constraints. In this paper, we identify a new tractable class of constraint problems involving global constraints of unbounded arity. To do so, we combine structural restrictions with the observation that some important types of global constraint do not distinguish between large classes of equivalent solutions.
